comment_text.mn79:5.4: Cp. SN 56.39:1.2. At DN 2:35.2 this is the attitude of a servant to the king.
comment_text.mn79:5.5: The same phrase is used of the Buddha’s assembly at MN 77:6.64, but with a different attitude: the Buddha’s assembly is poised expectantly, while Udāyī’s is gazing up at his face.
comment_text.mn79:6.4: For the Mahāsaṅgīti sati (“reminded”), PTS reads pīti here, but the phrase occurs at MN 89:4.2 and DN 9:6.32, both times with sati.
comment_text.mn79:6.7: The same claim is recorded at MN 14:17.2.
comment_text.mn79:7.5: Pubbanta and aparanta (literally “prior end” and “posterior end) are technical terms found exclusively in Buddhism, and only used in the context of speculative views. It seems the Buddha had a contextual reason to avoid the generic words for “past” (atīta) and “future” (anāgata), and I reflect that in my translation. Pubbanta is semantically identical with pubbakoti, the “first point” of existence or transmigration (SN 48.50:5.3). This is emphasized by Nāgarjuna, who introduces the terms pubbanta and aparanta immediately after discussing the “first point” of transmigration, and associates them with the “extremes” (anta) of eternalism and annihilationism (Mūlamadhyamakakārikā 25.20–23). Thus such talk is not merely about the past as in what happened yesterday, or the future as in what I’ll do next week, but unmoored speculations about the “first beginning” and the “final end”.
comment_text.mn79:7.7: The Buddha does not claim to see every fact and detail, but he comprehends the principle that underlies all suffering.
comment_text.mn79:8.1: Attabhāva is literally “the state of the self”, and refers to the body in which consciousness has been incarnated. While attā usually has a psychological or metaphysical sense, it sometimes means the “body”, a usage found also in the Sanskrit ātman (eg. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.2.4).
comment_text.mn79:8.3: The curious mud-goblin (paṁsupisācaka) is similarly mentioned at Ud 4.4:7.3.
comment_text.mn79:9.3: For more on this theory see note on MN 80:2.4.
comment_text.mn79:11.1: The statement on the “splendor of the self after death” is not found in the parallel at MA 208.
comment_text.mn79:18.1: Ābhā nanubhonti (“luminosity makes no impression”) is glossed as obhāsaṁ na vaḷañjanti, “does not partake of the light”. At AN 4.127:1.4 the same phrase, in regard to the space where the light of the sun does not reach, is glossed pabhā nappahonti, i.e. “light is ineffective”. Compare ananubhūtaṁ at MN 49:11.1.
comment_text.mn79:23.5: “Grounded practice” is ākāravatī paṭipadā, for which compare the “grounded faith” (ākāravatī saddhā) of MN 47:16.1 and MN 60:4.1.
comment_text.mn79:46.4: “Water ladle” (udañcanika, variant uddekanika, commentary udakavāraka) is a unique term. Read udañchanika in the sense “(ladle) for drawing water” (cp. Sanskrit ākarṣa for Pali añchana). | The terms udakamaṇika (“water jar”) and udañchanika (“water ladle”) pun on Udāyī’s name.

root_text.mn79:3.9: Atha kho te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṁ.

root_text.mn79:4.5: Cirassaṁ kho, bhante, bhagavā imaṁ pariyāyamakāsi yadidaṁ idhāgamanāya.
root_text.mn79:4.9: Sakuludāyīpi kho paribbājako aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn79:4.10: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho sakuludāyiṁ paribbājakaṁ bhagavā etadavoca:

root_text.mn79:5.1: “Tiṭṭhatesā, bhante, kathā yāya mayaṁ etarahi kathāya sannisinnā.
root_text.mn79:5.2: Nesā, bhante, kathā bhagavato dullabhā bhavissati pacchāpi savanāya.
root_text.mn79:5.3: Yadāhaṁ, bhante, imaṁ parisaṁ anupasaṅkanto homi athāyaṁ parisā anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ kathentī nisinnā hoti;
root_text.mn79:5.4: yadā ca kho ahaṁ, bhante, imaṁ parisaṁ upasaṅkanto homi athāyaṁ parisā mamaññeva mukhaṁ ullokentī nisinnā hoti:
root_text.mn79:5.5: ‘yaṁ no samaṇo udāyī dhammaṁ bhāsissati taṁ sossāmā’ti;
root_text.mn79:5.6: yadā pana, bhante, bhagavā imaṁ parisaṁ upasaṅkanto hoti athāhañceva ayañca parisā bhagavato mukhaṁ ullokentā nisinnā homa:
root_text.mn79:5.7: ‘yaṁ no bhagavā dhammaṁ bhāsissati taṁ sossāmā’”ti.
root_text.mn79:6.2: “Purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paṭijānamāno ‘carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paccupaṭṭhitan’ti.
root_text.mn79:6.3: So mayā pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puṭṭho samāno aññenaññaṁ paṭicari, bahiddhā kathaṁ apanāmesi, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsi.
root_text.mn79:6.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁyeva ārabbha sati udapādi:
root_text.mn79:6.5: ‘aho nūna bhagavā, aho nūna sugato. Yo imesaṁ dhammānaṁ sukusalo’”ti.
root_text.mn79:6.6: “Ko pana so, udāyi, sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paṭijānamāno ‘carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paccupaṭṭhitan’ti, yo tayā pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puṭṭho samāno aññenaññaṁ paṭicari, bahiddhā kathaṁ apanāmesi kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsī”ti?
root_text.mn79:7.1: “Yo kho, udāyi, anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussareyya, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussareyya, so vā maṁ pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puccheyya, taṁ vāhaṁ pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puccheyyaṁ;
root_text.mn79:7.2: so vā me pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheyya, tassa vāhaṁ pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheyyaṁ.
root_text.mn79:7.3: Yo kho, udāyi, dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passeyya cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajāneyya, so vā maṁ aparantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puccheyya, taṁ vāhaṁ aparantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puccheyyaṁ;
root_text.mn79:7.4: so vā me aparantaṁ ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheyya, tassa vāhaṁ aparantaṁ ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheyyaṁ.
root_text.mn79:7.5: Api ca, udāyi, tiṭṭhatu pubbanto, tiṭṭhatu aparanto.
root_text.mn79:7.7: imasmiṁ sati idaṁ hoti, imassuppādā idaṁ uppajjati;
root_text.mn79:7.8: imasmiṁ asati idaṁ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṁ nirujjhatī”ti.
root_text.mn79:8.1: “Ahañhi, bhante, yāvatakampi me iminā attabhāvena paccanubhūtaṁ tampi nappahomi sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anussarituṁ,
root_text.mn79:8.2: kuto panāhaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarissāmi, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarissāmi, seyyathāpi bhagavā?

root_text.mn79:8.4: kuto panāhaṁ dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passissāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānissāmi, seyyathāpi bhagavā?

root_text.mn79:8.8: imasmiṁ sati idaṁ hoti, imassuppādā idaṁ uppajjati;
root_text.mn79:8.9: imasmiṁ asati idaṁ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṁ nirujjhatī’ti tañca pana me bhiyyoso mattāya na pakkhāyati.
root_text.mn79:8.10: Appeva nāmāhaṁ, bhante, sake ācariyake bhagavato cittaṁ ārādheyyaṁ pañhassa veyyākaraṇenā”ti.

root_text.mn79:24.2: “Katamā pana sā, bhante, ākāravatī paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti?
root_text.mn79:25.1: “Idhudāyi, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
root_text.mn79:25.2: vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
root_text.mn79:25.3: pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati—
root_text.mn79:25.4: ayaṁ kho sā, udāyi, ākāravatī paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
root_text.mn79:25.5: “Na kho sā, bhante, ākāravatī paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya, sacchikato hissa, bhante, ettāvatā ekantasukho loko hotī”ti.
root_text.mn79:25.6: “Na khvāssa, udāyi, ettāvatā ekantasukho loko sacchikato hoti;
root_text.mn79:25.7: ākāravatī tveva sā paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
root_text.mn79:26.1: Evaṁ vutte, sakuludāyissa paribbājakassa parisā unnādinī uccāsaddamahāsaddā ahosi:
root_text.mn79:26.2: “ettha mayaṁ anassāma sācariyakā, ettha mayaṁ anassāma sācariyakā.
root_text.mn79:26.3: Na mayaṁ ito bhiyyo uttaritaraṁ pajānāmā”ti.
root_text.mn79:26.4: Atha kho sakuludāyī paribbājako te paribbājake appasadde katvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn79:27.1: “kittāvatā panāssa, bhante, ekantasukho loko sacchikato hotī”ti?
root_text.mn79:27.2: “Idhudāyi, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ … upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn79:27.3: Yā tā devatā ekantasukhaṁ lokaṁ upapannā tāhi devatāhi saddhiṁ santiṭṭhati sallapati sākacchaṁ samāpajjati.
root_text.mn79:27.4: Ettāvatā khvāssa, udāyi, ekantasukho loko sacchikato hotī”ti.
root_text.mn79:28.1: “Etassa nūna, bhante, ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ carantī”ti?
root_text.mn79:28.2: “Na kho, udāyi, ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.
root_text.mn79:28.3: Atthi kho, udāyi, aññeva dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca, yesaṁ sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ carantī”ti.
root_text.mn79:28.4: “Katame pana te, bhante, dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca yesaṁ sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ carantī”ti?
root_text.mn79:29-36.1: “Idhudāyi, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā …pe…
root_text.mn79:37.1: so ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
root_text.mn79:37.2: vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn79:37.3: Ayampi kho, udāyi, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.
root_text.mn79:38-40.1: Puna caparaṁ, udāyi, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā … dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
root_text.mn79:38-40.4: Ayampi kho, udāyi, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.
root_text.mn79:41.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn79:41.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn79:41.3: Ayampi kho, udāyi, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.
root_text.mn79:42.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn79:42.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
root_text.mn79:42.3: Ayampi kho, udāyi, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.
root_text.mn79:43.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn79:43.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti …pe… ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti … ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
root_text.mn79:43.3: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti … ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti … ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn79:44.1: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
root_text.mn79:44.3: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn79:44.4: Ayampi kho, udāyi, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.
root_text.mn79:44.5: Ime kho, udāyi, dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca yesaṁ sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ carantī”ti.
root_text.mn79:45.1: Evaṁ vutte, sakuludāyī paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn79:45.3: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.mn79:45.4: Esāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.mn79:45.5: Labheyyāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyaṁ upasampadan”ti.
root_text.mn79:46.1: Evaṁ vutte, sakuludāyissa paribbājakassa parisā sakuludāyiṁ paribbājakaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn79:46.2: “mā bhavaṁ, udāyi, samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṁ cari;
root_text.mn79:46.3: mā bhavaṁ, udāyi, ācariyo hutvā antevāsīvāsaṁ vasi.
root_text.mn79:46.4: Seyyathāpi nāma udakamaṇiko hutvā udañcaniko assa, evaṁ sampadamidaṁ bhoto udāyissa bhavissati.
root_text.mn79:46.5: Mā bhavaṁ, udāyi, samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṁ cari;
root_text.mn79:46.6: mā bhavaṁ, udāyi, ācariyo hutvā antevāsīvāsaṁ vasī”ti.
root_text.mn79:46.7: Iti hidaṁ sakuludāyissa paribbājakassa parisā sakuludāyiṁ paribbājakaṁ antarāyamakāsi bhagavati brahmacariyeti.

translation_text.mn79:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
translation_text.mn79:1.3: Now at that time the wanderer Sakuludāyī was residing together with a large assembly of wanderers in the monastery of the wanderers in the peacocks’ feeding ground.
translation_text.mn79:2.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.
translation_text.mn79:2.3: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Rājagaha.
translation_text.mn79:2.4: Why don’t I visit the wanderer Sakuludāyī at the monastery of the wanderers in the peacocks’ feeding ground?”
translation_text.mn79:2.5: Then the Buddha went to the monastery of the wanderers.
translation_text.mn79:3.1: Now at that time, Sakuludāyī was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a colossal racket. They engaged in all kinds of low talk, such as
translation_text.mn79:3.2: talk about kings, bandits, and chief ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
translation_text.mn79:3.3: Sakuludāyī saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn79:3.5: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.
translation_text.mn79:3.7: The venerable likes quiet and praises quiet.
translation_text.mn79:3.8: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
translation_text.mn79:4.4: Welcome to the Blessed One, sir!
translation_text.mn79:4.5: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
translation_text.mn79:4.6: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”
translation_text.mn79:4.8: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
translation_text.mn79:4.9: while Sakuludāyī took a low seat and sat to one side.
translation_text.mn79:4.11: “Udāyī, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
translation_text.mn79:5.1: “Sir, leave aside what we were sitting talking about just now.
translation_text.mn79:5.2: It won’t be hard for you to hear about that later.
translation_text.mn79:5.3: When I don’t come to the assembly, they sit and engage in all kinds of low talk.
translation_text.mn79:5.4: But when I have come to the assembly, they sit gazing up at my face alone, thinking,
translation_text.mn79:5.5: ‘Whatever the ascetic Udāyī teaches, we shall listen to it.’
translation_text.mn79:5.6: But when the Buddha has come to the assembly, both myself and the assembly sit gazing up at your face, thinking,
translation_text.mn79:5.7: ‘Whatever the Buddha teaches, we shall listen to it.’”
translation_text.mn79:6.1: “Well then, Udāyī, suggest something for me to talk about.”
translation_text.mn79:6.2: “Sir, a few days ago someone was claiming to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus: ‘Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.’
translation_text.mn79:6.3: When I asked them a question about the first beginning, they dodged the issue, distracted the discussion with irrelevant points, and displayed annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
translation_text.mn79:6.4: That reminded me of the Buddha:
translation_text.mn79:6.5: ‘Surely it must be the Blessed One, the Holy One who is so skilled in such matters.’”
translation_text.mn79:6.6: “But Udāyī, who was it that made such a claim and behaved in such a way?”
translation_text.mn79:6.7: “It was the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan, sir.”
translation_text.mn79:7.1: “Udāyī, someone who can recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details, might ask me a question about the first beginning, or I might ask them a question about the first beginning.
translation_text.mn79:7.2: And they might satisfy me with their answer, or I might satisfy them with my answer.
translation_text.mn79:7.3: Someone who, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, understands how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds might ask me a question about the final end, or I might ask them a question about the final end.
translation_text.mn79:7.4: And they might satisfy me with their answer, or I might satisfy them with my answer.
translation_text.mn79:7.5: Nevertheless, Udāyī, leave aside the first beginning and the final end.
translation_text.mn79:7.6: I shall teach you the Dhamma:
translation_text.mn79:7.7: ‘When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises.
translation_text.mn79:7.8: When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases.’”
translation_text.mn79:8.1: “Well sir, I can’t even recall with features and details what I’ve undergone in this incarnation.
translation_text.mn79:8.2: How should I possibly recollect my many kinds of past lives with features and details, like the Buddha?
translation_text.mn79:8.3: For I can’t even see a mud-goblin right now.
translation_text.mn79:8.4: How should I possibly, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, see sentient beings passing away and being reborn, like the Buddha?
translation_text.mn79:8.5: But then the Buddha told me,
translation_text.mn79:8.6: ‘Nevertheless, Udāyī, leave aside the first beginning and the final end.
translation_text.mn79:8.7: I shall teach you the Dhamma:
translation_text.mn79:8.8: “When this exists, this comes to be; due to the arising of this, this arises.
translation_text.mn79:8.9: When this doesn’t exist, this doesn’t come to be; due to the cessation of this, this ceases.”’ But that is even more unclear to me.
translation_text.mn79:8.10: Perhaps I might satisfy the Buddha by answering a question about my own tradition.”
translation_text.mn79:9.1: “But Udāyī, what is your own tradition?”
translation_text.mn79:9.3: ‘This is the ultimate splendor, this is the ultimate splendor.’”
translation_text.mn79:9.6: “Sir, the ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.”
translation_text.mn79:9.7: “But what is that ultimate splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer?”
translation_text.mn79:9.8: “Sir, the ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.”
translation_text.mn79:10.1: “Udāyī, you could draw this out for a long time.
translation_text.mn79:10.2: You say, ‘The ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’ But you don’t describe that splendor.
translation_text.mn79:10.3: Suppose a man was to say,
translation_text.mn79:10.4: ‘Whoever the finest lady in the land is, it is her that I want, her I desire!’
translation_text.mn79:10.6: ‘Worthy man, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know whether she’s an aristocrat, a brahmin, a peasant, or a menial?’
translation_text.mn79:10.9: ‘Mister, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know her name or clan? Whether she’s tall or short or medium? Whether her skin is black, brown, or dingy? What village, town, or city she comes from?’
translation_text.mn79:10.12: ‘Worthy man, do you desire someone who you’ve never even known or seen?’
translation_text.mn79:10.15: This being so, doesn’t that man’s statement turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
translation_text.mn79:10.17: “In the same way, you say, ‘The ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’ But you don’t describe that splendor.”
translation_text.mn79:11.1: “Worthy sir, suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally lustrous, eight-faceted, well-worked. When placed on a cream rug it would shine and glow and radiate. Such is the splendor of the self that is free of disease after death.”
translation_text.mn79:12.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: such a beryl gem, or a firefly in the dark of night?”
translation_text.mn79:12.3: “A firefly in the dark of night, sir.”
translation_text.mn79:13.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: a firefly in the dark of night, or an oil lamp in the dark of night?”
translation_text.mn79:13.3: “An oil lamp in the dark of night, sir.”
translation_text.mn79:14.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: an oil lamp in the dark of night, or a great mass of fire in the dark of night?”
translation_text.mn79:14.3: “A great mass of fire in the dark of night, sir.”
translation_text.mn79:15.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: a great mass of fire in the dark of night, or the Morning Star in the clear and cloudless heavens at the crack of dawn?”
translation_text.mn79:15.3: “The Morning Star in the clear and cloudless heavens at the crack of dawn, sir.”
translation_text.mn79:16.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: the Morning Star in the clear and cloudless heavens at the crack of dawn, or the full moon at midnight in the clear and cloudless heavens on the fifteenth day sabbath?”
translation_text.mn79:16.3: “The full moon at midnight in the clear and cloudless heavens on the fifteenth day sabbath, sir.”
translation_text.mn79:17.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: the full moon at midnight in the clear and cloudless heavens on the fifteenth day sabbath, or the sun at midday in the clear and cloudless heavens in the last month of the rainy season, in autumn?”
translation_text.mn79:17.3: “The sun at midday in the clear and cloudless heavens in the last month of the rainy season, in autumn, sir.”
translation_text.mn79:18.1: “Beyond this, Udāyī, I know very many gods on whom the luminosity of the sun and moon makes no impression.
translation_text.mn79:18.3: ‘The splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’
translation_text.mn79:18.4: But of the splendor inferior to a firefly you say, ‘This is the ultimate splendor.’ And you don’t describe that splendor.”
translation_text.mn79:19.1: “The Blessed One has cut short the discussion! The Holy One has cut short the discussion!”
translation_text.mn79:19.2: “But Udāyī, why do you say this?”
translation_text.mn79:19.4: “Sir, it says this in our own tradition:
translation_text.mn79:19.5: ‘This is the ultimate splendor, this is the ultimate splendor.’
translation_text.mn79:19.6: But when pursued, pressed, and grilled on our own tradition, we turned out to be vacuous, hollow, and mistaken.”
translation_text.mn79:20.1: “But Udāyī, is there a world of perfect happiness? And is there a grounded practice for realizing a world of perfect happiness?”
translation_text.mn79:20.2: “Sir, it says this in our own tradition:
translation_text.mn79:20.3: ‘There is a world of perfect happiness. And there is a grounded practice for realizing a world of perfect happiness.’”
translation_text.mn79:21.1: “Well, what is that grounded practice for realizing a world of perfect happiness?”
translation_text.mn79:21.2: “Sir, it’s when someone gives up killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, and lying. And they proceed having undertaken some kind of mortification.
translation_text.mn79:21.3: This is the grounded practice for realizing a world of perfect happiness.”
translation_text.mn79:22.2: On an occasion when someone refrains from killing living creatures, is their self perfectly happy at that time, or does it have both pleasure and pain?”
translation_text.mn79:22.5: On an occasion when someone refrains from stealing …
translation_text.mn79:22.9: lying, is their self perfectly happy at that time, or does it have both pleasure and pain?”
translation_text.mn79:22.12: On an occasion when someone undertakes and follows some kind of mortification, is their self perfectly happy at that time, or does it have both pleasure and pain?”
translation_text.mn79:22.15: Is a perfectly happy world realized by relying on a practice of mixed pleasure and pain?”
translation_text.mn79:23.1: “The Blessed One has cut short the discussion! The Holy One has cut short the discussion!”
translation_text.mn79:23.2: “But Udāyī, why do you say this?”
translation_text.mn79:23.4: “Sir, it says this in our own tradition:
translation_text.mn79:23.5: ‘There is a world of perfect happiness. And there is a grounded practice for realizing a world of perfect happiness.’
translation_text.mn79:23.6: But when pursued, pressed, and grilled on our own tradition, we turned out to be vacuous, hollow, and mistaken.
translation_text.mn79:23.7: But sir, is there a world of perfect happiness? And is there a grounded practice for realizing a world of perfect happiness?”
translation_text.mn79:24.1: “There is a world of perfect happiness, Udāyī. And there is a grounded practice for realizing a world of perfect happiness.”
translation_text.mn79:24.2: “Well sir, what is that grounded practice for realizing a world of perfect happiness?”
translation_text.mn79:25.1: “It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption.
translation_text.mn79:25.2: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption.
translation_text.mn79:25.3: With the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption.
translation_text.mn79:25.4: This is the grounded practice for realizing a world of perfect happiness.”
translation_text.mn79:25.5: “Sir, that’s not the grounded practice for realizing a world of perfect happiness. At that point a perfectly happy world has already been realized.”
translation_text.mn79:25.6: “No, Udāyī, at that point a perfectly happy world has not been realized.
translation_text.mn79:25.7: This is the grounded practice for realizing a world of perfect happiness.”
translation_text.mn79:26.1: When he said this, Sakuludāyī’s assembly made an uproar, a colossal racket,
translation_text.mn79:26.2: “In that case, we’re lost, and so are our traditional teachings! We’re lost, and so are our traditional teachings!
translation_text.mn79:26.3: We know nothing higher than this!”
translation_text.mn79:26.4: Then Sakuludāyī, having quieted those wanderers, said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn79:27.1: “Well sir, at what point is a perfectly happy world realized?”
translation_text.mn79:27.2: “It’s when, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption.
translation_text.mn79:27.3: There are deities who have been reborn in a perfectly happy world. That mendicant associates with them, converses, and engages in discussion.
translation_text.mn79:27.4: It’s at this point that a perfectly happy world has been realized.”
translation_text.mn79:28.1: “Surely the mendicants must lead the spiritual life under the Buddha for the sake of realizing this perfectly happy world?”
translation_text.mn79:28.2: “No, Udāyī, the mendicants don’t lead the spiritual life under me for the sake of realizing this perfectly happy world.
translation_text.mn79:28.3: There are other things that are finer, for the sake of which the mendicants lead the spiritual life under me.”
translation_text.mn79:29-36.1: “It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed. …
translation_text.mn79:37.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.mn79:37.2: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption.
translation_text.mn79:37.3: This is one of the finer things for the sake of which the mendicants lead the spiritual life under me.
translation_text.mn79:38-40.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption …
translation_text.mn79:38-40.4: This too is one of the finer things.
translation_text.mn79:41.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn79:41.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn79:41.3: This too is one of the finer things.
translation_text.mn79:42.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn79:42.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn79:42.3: This too is one of the finer things.
translation_text.mn79:43.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn79:43.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
translation_text.mn79:43.3: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
translation_text.mn79:44.1: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn79:44.2: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn79:44.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn79:44.4: This too is one of the finer things.
translation_text.mn79:44.5: These are the finer things for the sake of which the mendicants lead the spiritual life under me.”
translation_text.mn79:45.1: When he had spoken, Sakuludāyī said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn79:45.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.mn79:45.4: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn79:45.5: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
translation_text.mn79:46.1: When he said this, Sakuludāyī’s assembly said to him,
translation_text.mn79:46.2: “Worthy Udāyī, don’t lead the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama.
translation_text.mn79:46.3: You have been a tutor; don’t live as a pupil.
translation_text.mn79:46.4: You’ll end up like a water jar that turns into a water ladle.
translation_text.mn79:46.5: Worthy Udāyī, don’t lead the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama.
translation_text.mn79:46.6: You have been a tutor; don’t live as a pupil.”
translation_text.mn79:46.7: And that’s how the wanderer Sakuludāyī’s own assembly prevented him from leading the spiritual life under the Buddha.
